Why is this guy all about wireless charging? It takes longer to charge using wireless charging. 20% of the power running through your device will be wasted — not great in terms of conserving energy. For the most part, you can't use your phone while it charges wirelessly. If you take your phone off the wireless charger to do anything, it'll stop charging. You can't text comfortably without lifting your phone off the charger, you can't sit on the couch and scroll through websites, and you can't even take a phone call properly. But with a cord, you can do all those tasks while staying plugged in. Also, these wireless chargers are technically not wireless. They still have to be plugged into an outlet. The only wireless part about it is eliminating the wire between your phone and the charger. To me, it is not practical and more of a gimmick to show off to friends.

Writing this after receiving the repair bill for water damage of my Oneplus 8 pro.

Bought this device in November 2020. Used it for close to 2 months. Until one day I put it to test of water resistance. Half immersed in water for about 20seconds. The fingerprint reader stopped working. Later that day device dropped dead. Took it to Oneplus authorised centre(Vytilla, Kochi) next day. They said water has entered the device as the water indicators near the sim tray has turned red. After 3 days I called them to receive the news that repair would cost an estimate of Rs. 40,000/- . Main board would cost around Rs. 24,000 and other damages extra. I was happy with my Oneplus 8PRO until this moment. But clearly IP68 rating fooled me into buying this device.

In their advertisement, Robert Downey Jr jumps into swimming pool with it!!!...SERIOUSLY....my device couldn't handle half immersed into clean pipe water for 20 seconds!!! Feeling cheated. Would never buy a Oneplus device again

@Sphy well the funny thing is, I took it home from service after deciding to discard the device and that day evening the device switched on!!!  What if I had spend that amount of money???!!! Service centre guys told me the screen and board needs to be replace but now they are fine!!! But The fingerprint scanner is not working, earpiece speaker and one of the sim slot not working
@Sarath Paul yup, or they actually just messed up your phone, but that was a possibility that isn't too rare. Just sent it back it is not acceptable
@Sphy on first dip????

Well after some time the rubber gets off, depends on how much you use the device and how much it heats it gets off. In every phone it gets off after some time so you should never trust the IP rating in any phone brand. It does suck tho but just so you know, you were never meant to think that its 100% water resistant, even in Apple's products.

I feel like wireless charging is a worthless feature and more of a detriment than anything and it shouldn't be a flagship feature. It's another component to cram in were you could get a a hundred or two more mAh into the battery or something. I mean from a engineering standpoint, it's less efficient as you're radiating electricity to a coil through a solid material like glass or whatever the case back is instead of running current directly to the battery via a literal closed circuit connection. By default a lot of that power is going to just radiate and not be caught by the coils so you need more power for the same charge speed as a wired connection. What isn't caught by the coil is just going to warm your phone. And it's not like it's true "wireless" as you still have to leave your phone stationary on a charging dock of some sort so it's not like you can actively use your phone as it's wirelessly charging seeing as it has to pretty much contact the dock.

At least with a cable you can still answer and use your phone because the a wire is always easier to work with than having to have your phone physically contact a plate at a specific point. But wait, I hear you guys coming at me about wireless head/ear phones and stuff eliminating the need to answer your phone physically while it's charging... to that I say, you can also use those wireless head/ear phones while your phone is wired. There is literally no benefit to wireless charging unless they figure out a way to wirelessly charge while being at least a meter or 3 feet away from the charging dock without your phone turning into a literal lightning rod. Again from an engineering standpoint you will always get faster charging at less power when wired because physics.

I have ordered this phone, and will be charging it nightly on 5W wireless, and would be doing so, if possible, even if it was able to charge faster on Qi wireless.

Lithium batteries degrade, and for phones, where you typically get pretty close to a full charge cycle per day, the capacity loss is noticeable pretty soon - usually after six months, definitely after a year, and markedly so after two years. But degradation isn't only dependent on the number of charge cycles. Batteries degrade faster at very low or high state of charge. So if I go to bed at midnight and charge to 100% by 0:50AM every night, it will be sitting an awful lot at 100% SoC, degrading the battery. Charging it fast also in itself increases degradation. There is very little value for me in my phone being at 100% while I am sleeping, and much greater value in having the battery capacity remain close to "as new" for longer.

With 4510 mAh and a LiFePO4-type battery cell (nominal 3.3V, lower than typical Lithium-ion chemistries and therefore not comparable by looking at mAh, which is the spec everyone quotes) we have 4.51*3.3 = 14.8 Wh of energy. At 5W that would take slightly under 3 hours from empty to full, but the 5W are surely before charging losses, and I bet they are fairly substantial (in percentage terms, the energy involved is comparable to seconds of driving a car, so eco-minded folks should look elsewhere to improve their CO2-e footprint!) and that it will in practice be more like 3W and 5 hours (3W * 5h = 15 Wh). That's pretty much perfect for overnight charging - less than you normally sleep, so you should seldom if ever not find a fully charged phone, but cutting the time sitting at 100% to about a quarter compared to the fast-charging method. And, again, the charging process itself is gentler to the battery this way.

For me, it's fine to use the wired charger for quick top-up charging should that be necessary. I wonder how quickly it will charge in my car (Model 3, I use the wired solution that comes as standard), as that would be a case where super fast charging would be an advantage, but as long as it charges at least as fast as my outgoing Galaxy S9 (now two years old and just barely able to last a day on a charge, and for the time being needing daily top-ups because the corona tracker app is a real battery killer), I am pretty confident it will work well for me.

Of course one cannot argue that it would be a bad thing if it supported faster wireless charging also on Qi. But at least for me, it's actually more important that I am able to restrict it to slower charging (though I suppose I could always achieve that by choosing a slow charger). I really wish it was possible to tweak charging more in software, just like you can in any electric car (where the battery is rather expensive and the product itself needs to last rather longer than two years).

IDK if the Android SDK allows third party apps to intervene, but I'm guessing they do not, as I haven't been able to find any third party app that allows me to say things like "I want charging to be completed by 7:00 AM daily" and "charge to 90% (instead of 100%)", which would be fairly simple to implement. The harder part is to explain to end-users who for the most part have neither any knowledge of nor any interest in the lifecycle characteristics of battery cells what the point would be! Apple has taken a first step on their latest laptops, but as is typical for them, it's just a toggle to tell the OS you will let it "optimize" battery "longevity" at some expense to battery "life" (since people think of battery "life" as how long one full charge will get them by). Apple's way is potentially awesome, but I doubt it is advanced enough to figure out what's optimal for _me_, for each individual user. If it is, bring it on Android too! Basically the optimum for anyone is to slowly charge the phone so it completes just before the phone is being used, and just enough so that it lasts the whole day. In practice, you can't predict the next day's needs with great accuracy, so you'll need a buffer, but I reckon all the data is there to figure out I can get by with, say, 80% on weekdays from 7:00 AM, and 95% on weekends from 8:30AM, and then slowly increase those (and, with it, unavoidably, degradation rate) as capacity decreases. In theory I could then experience the same stamina from my phone instead of it getting a bit worse all the time, until it has to charge to 100% and can no longer hide the degradation.

Looking forward to getting this phone. I think the Samsung is pretty good hardware, but I have been plagued with hangs in Chrome for a long time now, across system updates. Don't know if it's Google or Samsung who are to blame... It'll be interesting to see if the OnePlus manages to feel good for more than a year. My current employer lets me renew my phone every 2 years, and I frankly would be getting a cheaper phone if I paid out of my own pocket. While it's nice to have a flagship phone, I don't personally think they are that much better than the best budget phones! Got a Xiaomi A2 for a fraction of the cost for my mum, and though I haven't lived with it myself, my impression is that it offers a user like me 95% of the utility for 15% of the money (I'm in my mid 40s, not the selfie-generation, I hardly use social media, don't take many photos or video, play mostly only the game of chess which doesn't need 120 Hz or a powerful 3D engine...)

I just bought Oneplus 8 Pro 1 week ago and here is my thoughts. Battery is superb, I can get 5 hours of heavy usage (play PUBG few hours, take video in 1080/60fps and editing video) with 40-60% screen brightness and 9+ hours of light usage (read manga or watch YouTube) in the evening with 20-40%  screen brightness. Camera is comparable to Samsung in my Opinion because I own S10 and speakers are superb. One down side is the heating issues, you can only use the full brightness of 1000nits for few minutes only for shooting video, same goes for PUBG gaming in 65-100% screen brightness!!! Me in 2013:
Lumia 820: Flagship specs (for 2012)
Amazing 8.7 MP camera
Amazing build quality
Optical image stabilization
60 Hz refresh screen (most devices up to 2012 were 30 Hz)
Amazing prices
1.5 GHz dual core Snapdragon
Adreno 320
1 GB ram.
Fastest, smoothest scrolling în the world on Windows Phone 8.0, even better than iOS on iPhone 5 back then, vastly better than even Nexus 4.
Hell, I wasn't even bothered by the 800x480 rez on the 4.3" screen.
Some 700 nits max brightness? It was really bright for a 2012 device.

2020:
120 Hz
Over 1440p
1300 nits
HDR
Video interpolation
48 MP camera and some other goodies
SD 865
12 GB ram

Yeah, can't wait to be back on top of the world and have the phone feel fast for 5 years straight.

@Riju Das, well, read more. Write more. And get your writing evaluated constantly.
Grammar and syntax and structure are of paramount importance.
And then there is the readability itself. The way to improve on that is to find credible people to give you feedback, apart from friends and family, maybe even teachers.
When someone tells you something you've written is good or 'perfect', question them; ask them what makes it good, and why they like it.
And then you keep looking for people to evaluate your work until you find someone who says he/she doesn't like it. Find out why. And so on.
It is important to be extremely critical of yourself. You should be your own harshest critic.
Challenge every single word you use; ask yourself if it's superfluous or serves an actual purpose.
Keep editing, keep revising. And always look for ways to improve every line you write and speak; examine the voice, the choice of words, the cadence...
Oh, and also be consistent with how you use language. You should be as careful and meticulous with it in casual conversation and on social media as you would be when you sit down to write.

While I am disappointed at how much more expensive their phones have gotten, since price was a big reason I switched to them in the first place, I've been really happy with my OnePlus 5 over the past (almost) 3 years. With how much I use it, the fact that I'm still happy with it and hesitant to move on says a lot. 8GB of RAM and 128GB of storage plus a headphone jack for $530 new was a steal. I'm still unhappy about the headphone jack being gone and the 8 Pro being a few hundred dollars more than what I have now, but the quality of the 5 has made me confident in their abilities to make a good, long-lasting phone, so I'll probably end up with the 8 or 8T later this year.

After the OnePlus 7 pro I will not be able to buy a phone that has a notch or cut out hole for the camera. It's why it's still the best phone on the market for me. You cannot beat that seamless display from edge to edge. There's no reason to compromise in my opinion.

With the new software OTA update, the OnePlus Bullets Wireless Z, which were announced alongside the new smartphones, can be integrated with Dolby Atmos to provide you with better sound quality.

The update comes with version number OxygenOS 10.5.4. It adds Live Caption, optimizes the camera’s shooting experience and improved stability, optimizes the fingerprint unlock experience, adds contact notes info for incoming calls and more. Folks at 9to5Google were the first to report about rolling out the new update.

Here is the Complete Changelog:

System

1. Improved system stability
2. Improved icon display in status bar
3. Improved back gesture experience
4. OnePlus Bullets Wireless Z can now be integrated with Dolby Atmos for better sound quality
5. Added double-tap feature to wake up lockscreen in ambient display mode or off-screen condition
6. Added OnePlus Tips & Support section in Settings. Check out all the new features and answers to common issues here
7. Added Live Caption, this will detect speech in media and automatically generate captions [To enable: Settings-System-Accessibility-Live Caption]
8. Update Android Security Patch to 2020.03
9. Updated GMS package to 2020.02

Camera

1. Optimized the camera’s shooting experience and improved stability
2. Optimized the animation effect and improved interaction experience
3. Added video filter feature
4. Fingerprint Unlock
5. Optimized the fingerprint unlock experience when unlocking the device

Phone updates

1. Added contact notes info for incoming calls

Network updates

1. Optimized network data transmission performance and stability

Voice Assistant updates

1. Now you can wake up voice assistant of your choice just by long-pressing the power button [To enable: Settings-Buttons & gestures-Press and hold the power button-Choose the app you want to activate

The 147th Annual Meeting and Expo of the American Public Health Association (APHA) was held at the Pennsylvania Conference Center in Philadelphia, November 2 - 6, 2019.

During the gathering of 12,000 of the world's most influential public health professionals, many learned about the Chinese communist regime's large-scale extrajudicial killing of prisoners of conscience and religious adherents for organ transplants.


The CCP's state-sanctioned live organ harvesting drew attention during the 2019 APHA Annual Meeting

Founded in 1872, APHA is the world's oldest and most academically diverse public health organization. The 2019 meeting and expo was attended by representatives from governments, universities, research institutes, organizations, hospitals, and health care providers from around the world. There were also a large number of attendees from China and those studying abroad.

New York-based China Organ Harvest Research Center (COHRC) participated in the meeting for the third time with oral and poster presentations. COHRC revealed one of the most hideous human rights disasters of the 21st century, which alarmed participants.

Unlike black market organ trafficking in some countries, the Chinese Communist Party's (CCP) on-demand forced live organ transplants from prisoners of conscience are state-sanctioned and operated by the military and local institutions.

The COHRC exposed the CCP's live organ harvesting during the 27th International Congress of Transplant Society (TTS) in Spain in July 2018, the American Transplant Congress (ATC) in June 2019, and the 19th Congress of the European Society of Organ Transplant in Denmark in September 2019. At the end of October, the COHRC was invited to the annual meeting of the American Society of Bioethics and Humanity (ASBH). The COHRC shared its latest research results with special presentations on the nature, scale, organ source, driving factors, and impact of China's forced organ harvesting.

I don't think they should go that way as a company. They should focus on where they got famous : the 500 dollar flagship killer smartphone market.
Each and every year they drastically increase prices, trying to compete with Apple and Samsung. But I'm not sure a lot of people are willing to pay almost a thousand dollar for a Oneplus phone.

They should focus all that money they're investing on these expensive phones, on the 500 dollar phone market, trying to make the best phone possible for a significantly lower price than top smartphones.
That's basically where they got their notoriety : making great if not amazing phones, almost as good as Apple and Samsung, for half the price.
They should keep striving to get closer and closer to the top phones, while not increasing the price, by investing all the money they're making on RnD.

This is where they should stick. This is why so many people got on board with the company. Their motto was "trust us : we're gonna try to make the best phones possible, while not charging you insane prices like the big monsters that Apple and Samsung are" (obviously paraphrasing here). They used to want to be different than them, now they're becoming just like em.

Because they're gonna lose a lot of fans from the old days of the 500 dollar phones, and not win many new ones in my opinion.
Again, I don't know anybody who's gonna pay Apple money for a Oneplus device.
I sure as hell would rather get a brand new Iphone XS or 11 rather than a Oneplus, no doubt about that.

In this case I would apply the "if it ain't broke don't fix it" principle.

But that's just my opinion of course.

So i have a really hot take on this phone. One Plus has gone greedy and moved away from the things that made people passionate about these phones (imo). I like the design, i like the screen to body ratio and super thin bezels, i like the front camera position. I hate everything else about it. Wireless charging? Useless. IP rating? I dont shower with my phone. No headphone jack? They fucked up really hard on that. All the "best cameras"? Could be easily downgraded for majority of people without them noticing and those who need the super camera usually have professional cameras with them either way. To me OP was the one phone to give a middle finger to the flagship phones and give people what they actually need for a decent price. Now theyre making phones for the minority, those tech geeks who want the best stuff. With so many really good choices for sub $400-500, i cant see any reason why anyone should ever pay that much for a phone. Most people's computers cost way less, so why do you need a phone that expensive, when all you do is go on tinder, take a few pics every few months, play a game once in a while, and watch a few videos? I just dont get it anymore..

After dealing with OnePlus Customer Service all day today, all I can really say is: If you want to charge Flagship Prices, you need to have Flagship Customer Service.


Their website was having issues with items going in and out of stock constantly around the launch window, which is too be expected. I managed place on order for the phone, but while checking out it was having issues with the Accessories Bundle that they were promoting as a Free Launch Day Bundle. I assumed that it was just a website glitch, and processed the order. After all, the website advertised the Launch Day Bundle and mentioned nothing about it only being available for the first couple thousand orders. I went into Customer Service after having placed my order, and proceeded to be ignored and run around uselessly for hours with not a single agent doing anything to try to help me with the issue. Basically, they wanted to claim that the bundle was only for the first orders and that they couldn't do anything to help. This is despite the website claiming something different. I ended up cancelling my order as a result of it. Cancelled a $1300 phone order because their customer service wouldn't honor a $129 promotion. Their profit margin on the phone is probably a LOT more than the cost of the two accessories. Spending dollars to save nickels.

But in my car, sometimes it will connect instantly like it should, other times I have to go into the cars list of devices and manually select to pair with the device. I never had this issue with my Nexus 6P that I had last or my iPod touch 5th gen I used prior to that. Then half the time it doesn't load in the artist name, song name, and album name on the screen until I press "next" to go to the next song and then it will load. Occasionally when I skip to the next song it will just stop playing audio and the song name, artist, and album will go blank and the song time will just count up to 3 and then back to zero and it'll just keep doing that and I'll have to go into my stereo, disconnect the phone, and then reconnect it and it'll be fine. And then there are other times where it'll just randomly disconnect from my car all together and I have to go in and manually click to connect it again. And from the research I've been doing I see other people having the same issue in their cars as well.

Few things I do not like about OnePlus:

1. Proprietary charging solution. Now BOTH the wired AND wireless charging are proprietary. Just as annoying as Apple's lightning.

2. Bi-monthly security updates. If they are going to charge $900 and up, they'd better step it up and provide monthly security updates that must not fall behind more than 1 month. Right now, their patch level can lag behind as much as 3 months.

3. Annoying curved screen that reflects lights to smear viewable contents and constantly causes accidental touches.

Your view on proprietary is wrong as it still works with other products.  if your charger can only deliver 15w, why would you expect it to deliver 30w from a 3rd party that is not designed to do that? that wireless dock has to output  like 60w to deliver 30 effectively. Most of the charging tech is built in the charger which is why the phone doesn't get fried, both apple and Samsung got it stuck for years on theirs.  Now, electricity is not something you want to improvise with,  if battery cells are tweaked to a pattern that benefits from 6 amps, it is not OPPO/OP fault that others didnt discover it. Congratulations, all the tech reviewers. Your greedy requests have made the OnePlus phones so expensive now that I don't think I'm gonna be able to afford them anymore. We're normal people, first of all we don't get smartphones sent by manufacturers, we need to buy them using a thing called money. Okay tell me, why do I need IP68 certification on my phone, when I already know that it's pretty much water/dust resistant? I've been using OP5T for about two years now, and I've been literally washing it everyday, what's the fuss about IP rating? I've also been using wireless charging, but never felt the necessity of it. Camera bumps are getting larger everyday, so you cannot use the phone while putting it on the wireless charging pad anyway. So what's the big deal? Is putting the charging pin to the USB port that much of a hustle for you? And do you think normal human beings like us need a 30x or 100x zoom? We don't give a shit about the most minute differences in exposure levels or contrast or even saturation levels, we can always make that right by opening up an editing app! We are no pro photographers or videographers, we are just some ordinary people who loves to keep memories in pictures and upload a few on social media feeds, it'll be downsampled anyway. Practically speaking, most of the people use filters anyway, which makes these camera comparisons mostly redundant.
FFS, stop ruining our beloved smartphones. We want some practical devices for normal people, we don't need a long list of gimmicky features.

One plus has done a good job in putting the essentials like Wireless charging and IP rating which now makes the OP8 PRO a true flagship, but I don't see this phone as a winner.
For Christ's sake it is a 900$ phone and it is now time we grill this phone as we do the Samsungs and the Iphones.
One plus which was considered to be the king in charging speeds is nowhere near nowadays. It still has the ancient 30W charging junk since the past 3 or more years. Oppo, Vivo, Realme, Xiaomi now have atleast 50W charging in their upper mid range phones, which FYI are priced below 600$ with SD865.
The shitty wireless charging tech that only works at 5W with other wireless chargers is preposterous.
Let's be real nobody wants to dunk their phones in water, so wasting money on an IP certification was again a bad decison.
If you still need a GCAM mod on a 900$ smartphone then I wont consider buying that phone. Putting in a 48 MP SONY IMX586 wide angle/macro lens is the only good thing in the camera department. The primary sensor is still a 48 MP sensor whereas other companies have moved to 64 MP as a standard (and soon to 108 MP). The selfie camera is a bummer too.

All in all, OP8 pro is a phone that can only pretend to be a flagship, but well and truly it isn't.

@Aditya Varshney The problem is that with higher charging speeds batteries become bigger and heavier for the same capacity. These phones are already too heavy. Hardly anything is less than even 200 gms. In contrast the M31 with a 6000 mah battery with 15W charging is just 192 gms.

Samsung actually do a good job here. The S20 with a 4000 mah battery is just 163 gms. But that's with 25 watt charging not 30 Watt or 45 Watt or 60 Watt.

If they eliminate wireless charging they can also do a faux leather back that both looks good and avoids fingerprints and gives you the option of going bareback. The Oppo Find X2 Pro does that and looks really cool.

@James Power I somewhat agree with you, but one plus being the company which deals with high speed high performance won't settle for a smaller 20W charger. Why not go for both, a bigger battery and a high capacity charger, let's say 50W atleast. At 899$, It is a flagship phone now we should remember that, so let's not cut corners and ask for the best what we want

I think ip68 water resistance is a real upgrade. I don't want half-assed assurances instead of an official rigorous test. But wireless charging is utterly pointless. That and the curved screen which impedes gameplay and makes the phone harder to protect

As for camera I think they're saving those improvements for the OP8t Pro.

But continuing to talk about inessentials, they could even go for a 90 hz display so you don't have to keep switching it for the benefit of the battery. They could also do a 5000 math battery which is just as light and small but with 20W efficient charging so it charges up in 90 minutes. Most people prefer the assurance of long battery life over unnecessarily rapid charging. And with those cuts to production cost, 850$ for a 12 gb RAM, 256 gb storage model, and 999$ for a 12 gb RAM 512 gb storage model and maybe 1300$ for a 16 gb RAM, 1 tb storage Maclaren edition with some kind of ceramic back just for the flex of showing what a big company Oneplus have become.

Honestly, I don't get the criticism one plus is getting for putting out a flagship model. It is not that they are charging more for the same specs, you are getting a better camera and some additional features like wireless and blah blah and arguably these upgrades will cost 100-200 bucks more than what we are used to. I think it is better for a company to offer choices for different subsets of consumers, so someone like Marques can get a good camera and wireless, on the other hand, I will be happy with a decent camera and fast charging. So, in my opinion, one plus 7 is still the model to go, unless you want a flagship. Rather than shitting on a company that is still offering you the cheapest flagship, you can use your mind to prioritize the features you need and get the suited model or even some other phone.


That said, since one plus has now ventured into flagship territory, they must spread out their models for different ranges. It is not wise just have $900 phones launched in a year. Either they should call this flagship series some other name, or launch a new budget series. Although it will be ironic to have flagships and flagship killer by the same company, it is the way to go if one plus wants to retain its customer base. It will be unwise of the company to think apple cultist or Samsung fanbois would switch to 1+ just coz they are offering a better phone. If things worked that way, we won't be having a $1200 i-box in 2020.

The biggest issue with the curved edge screen is it breaks very easily with a case on it.  The case cannot come up higher than the sides of the screen like flat screen phones or it would cover up the curved sides.  Therefore it leaves the screen wide open to contact the ground when you drop it.  Terrible design and why?  Just because it looks cool?  What a dumb trade-off.  Nobody cares about curved edges and they catch all kinds of glare and accidental touches.  Hard pass.

My mom is probably the only person I know who wants a fancy camera on her phone. The 120 hz display is nice; I have messed with a phone that has it and there is a noticeable difference. However, I don't need it. 60 hz is plenty for everyday use unless you game on your phone or something like that. I myself prefer higher resolution phone's, but people don't usually know how to adjust them to get the most out of the higher resolution. Beyond this sentence I am not going to mention wireless charging.  I can understand getting a phone with 8 gigs of RAM max, but 12 gigs is wayy overkill. You can run full desktop operating systems on 4 - 8 gigs of RAM; 16 is the usual for gaming. There are no games that I have found that can't get by (easily) with 4 gigs of RAM. Double that 4 gig number for growth is ok but triple is wayy overkill; at least for mobile.

I'll leave this here.
Do 4K 60FPS Video with the main lens, and you'll see how bad the quality is. I can bet OP8 Pro will be the same. In my OP7 Pro recording video on whatever setting sucks with built in camera app as well as with GCam. There is a lot of glare, noise, making video look like it was recorded on 300$ phone. Check my channel video (these with "djing") to see for yourself. I mean it, it's not clickbait, I just want you to see for yourself how bad the camera is when recording video. People talk about taking photos with phones these days, ok, in good lighting conditions, OP is quite decent for the price... But man, don't get yourself pulled by how pics and videos looks in good conditions... Because when you need the quality in any other than "good" conditions it's just not there... They are so much focused on the photo side of the camera, that video and mic quality is just not there. So basically the phone is average, it's just software that make pictures look good, but not videos. It's like your car looks fast and aggressive but has 15sec 0-60mph.
I'm disappointed that after 3 years of ownership of OP3, and now one year of OP7 Pro, I won't ever buy OP phone again. It cost nearly as much as Pixel, IPhone 11, and has the same price as Galaxy S20. Unless they come up with cameras up to the price, I just don't want another OP. I used to LOVE the OP. They were doing the impossible. But man, they're now at 1000Euro price point. At this price point, 120Hz, fast (wireless) charging and speed is not everything. What's more the speed in OP is mainly because the little things like fast and smooth animations, which doesn't hold back apps from loading. ​@sanji Vinsmoke Wrong. The most VOLUME is in the budget market, not the most profit. The more expensive phones are by far more profitable. There's a reason Apple holds 65% of the entire smartphone industry profits. Think about it:
It costs about $490 to manufacture an iPhone 11 Pro Max (without marketing, RnD, and other intangibles). Lets say that a budget phone like the Moto G cost $100 to manufacture. The iPhone 11 Pro Max will sell for $1099 while the Moto G sells at $200. The iPhone 11 Pro Max sees a 55% profit margin compared to a 50% profit margin for the Moto G. That 5% difference may seem small, but that becomes a massive difference at higher volumes. Motorola would have to sell 6 phones for every 1 phone apple sells to make the same $600 profits. This becomes even more difficult since there are infinitely more phones competing in the budget segment than the flagship segment. In addition to that, Apple will have a far easier time getting its users to buy accessories, services and other small post purchase investments (iCloud, Apple Music, Apple Arcade, etc). I could go on, but this comment is already way too long lol.
@Nik3 yeah but the most profit is in the budget market..
@KingDavid sadly yea
@KingDavid Well said.

If you understand business, then you know there was no chance it would ever last. OnePlus' only goal with releasing extremely affordable phones was market penetration. As they became more established in the industry, they raised the price more and more. The truth is, all these companies want are bigger and bigger profit margins. As much as Android users mock Apple, all the Android OEMs see Apple's bottom line and dream of seeing those numbers. It's just the truth

Curved edges suck, because hard glass protectors that have to be curved as well often don't fit it perfectly. Then you get lifting (especially when combined with a lot of cases) or dust around the edges between the protector and the phone. The Galaxy S7 Active, to me, was one of the best form factors.  The screen was slightly soft which means during drop testing the regular S7 broke the first time, while the they stopped the S7 Active after 50(!). This necessitated the use of a hard glass screen protector for the scratch resistance, but because the edges didn't fall-away it was no problem at all. You could safely run it without a case, and had a big battery for it's size (4,000 mah). Screen real estate is great, but I miss the home button now and then.  Thanks for the review!

One question: What is the point of wireless charging if you have to put your phone locked to a certain spot (in this case, this stand-like charger)? It's not any more "moveable" than wired, whatsoever.

Now I see it more clearly. Basically
1. It's the ease of shoving it down and picking it up at any time.
2. You don't have a port that could potentially break.
3. You can't have compatibility issues, as long as your phone can charge wirelessly.

On the other hand, though
1. It costs quite a lot as of now. Buying cables comes out usually cheaper for the time you will be using your phone.
2. Also, never have I ever in my life break the charging port on any phone. I'm sure it might happen to some people by accident, but I don't think it's that likely/common.
3. Lastly, if you think about it, wired is actually more "moveable", as of now. No matter how you charge, you're "locked" into a small area if you have to use your phone while doing so. But. With wired, you can pick up the device, and you can move in a 1 or 2 meter radius, which you can't do with wireless charging, as it has to lay completely in a certain spot.

All in all, it's some cool tech, no doubt, but we have a long way to go until it becomes a useful feature you can use 100 out of 100 cases. Until then, I think it's better to just use cable (considering that you'll most likely use that device for 2 years, it's much cheaper to buy new cables, should you need to do so)

I've asked this before and I have to ask again:
'why phone get 1440p 120Hz OLED but pc not'
@Haqmaan Mahroof actually iirc oled and amoled screens have 1ms response times
Phone display neither have G sync or free sync technology nor quick response time ( 1ms ) and other gaming technology as well..so it wont cost them much to make an OLED panel for phone.
OLED response time will be 20ms or more .. which gives a significant disadvantages for gamers who plays fast paced games

OLED screens are hard to make at large sizes, meaning OLED displays for PC would be very expensive. Very expensive. TV's can be made oled because high profit margin, same with phones. Monitors dont have as high of a profit margin. Oled screens have somewhere between 50-30% failure rate (meaning 50-30% of the ones made wont work)

Its simple really PC's generally have still images on screen and monitors veibg larger are more expensive so many pc companies refuse to release them until they find a solution to screen burn especially since phones are replaced far more frequently than monitors

I want to say a few things. They are:

1) The 5G in the Oneplus 8 Pro has the Qualcomm X55 modem which supports both sub-6 & mmWave 5G.

2) The Oneplus 8 Pro will be offered on the Verizon network.

3) Samsung is currently working on a new eUFS 3.1 that is much faster than the current UFS 3.0 standard. Hopefully it'll be ready enough to debut in the "Note20."

4) I totally agree with giving users the option for 90Hz. That is where I'd run a phone with that type of display. I don't think it'd be that difficult to incorporate a slider toggle option that shows: 60Hz --------- 90Hz --------- 120Hz. Actually, I think the 90Hz display technology is now mature enough to even eliminate a 60Hz option altogether. All we need is for the app developers to start optimizing their apps to take full advantage of higher refresh rates, but the displays are ready for it.

5) Oneplus should start producing a phone line with a built-in stylus to compete with the Samsung Note series. I don't think any smartphone manufacturer is touching Samsung in that aspect.

I've had the 7pro for over 6 months now and I can honestly say its truly worth it as I was considering a Note 10+ or S10+.

You can see the difference between 90hz and 60hz as I find other phones quite laggy compared to mine especially when I am scrolling quite fast through WhatsApp/Facebook.

The only issues I have are the following:

1) accidental presses due to curved screen. This is probably my biggest irritation however it doesn't happen much only sometimes when I'm watching YouTube.

2) Fingerprint reader fails about 2/10 like you said. Doesn't bother me much because again the reader is a lot quicker than Samsung etc.

Given the price and the price drop now. Definitely highly recommend. If anything the 8Pro doesn't look like an upgrade. Wireless charging is moot because the standard charger is so quick. I've never had to worry about my phone charge and I am a heavy user. Quick 15 min charge takes it from 1% to about 30-40%. You can pretty much use that for another 2-3 hours heavy use or 6+ hours light use.

Normally on the same page of you and I get where you are coming from but this video felt like it was going very easy on a phone that just jumped $200-$150 from the last model.

This phone compared to last year has
-IP rating
-Wireless charging
-better camera spec
-120hz

Okay that all seems great. Until you remember that
-OnePlus phones have been water resistant for a long time just without the IP rating.
-Its actually slow wireless charging unless u are using a $70 accessory and the reason people like wireless charging is generally for the convenience so only have 5W on all other chargers makes it almost useless
-And 120hz while faster doesn't offer as big of a jump from 90hz, and drains significantly more battery. That doesn't make it a negative but as you said not having 90zh option is forcing people to make a choice on a now flagship. That plus the holepunch that is now part of the design. (Also wanted to add that this was likely a change due to every reviewer criticizing it when it was first released so just thinking that you prefer holepunch. Clearly everyone's mindsets have changed in the last year but with how early development start on these phones they were probably taking the critism from everyone that pop-ups cant be trusted)

Overall as you said this is a great phone, and not has all the flagship specs but the video felt like a comparison to the S20/S20U which was not a very good phone for what it offers. I find it hard to believe that these improvements are worth the $200 more money costumers were spending last year. The only thing that is undoubtedly a net positive is the enhanced camera that does seem to be much better than previous models.

I don't know. Maybe I'm stuck in my ways and am tired of the entire market moving towards $1,000 flagships. But this phone doesn't leave me awed and based on others I feel like it is a great option for people who wanted an S20 but weak when compared to last year's phone.

Sorry for rambling. Just very much caught off guard with this one.

I have a question that has been bugging me and I figured i would throw it in here. Would a 120Hz screen on an IPhone really make a difference to the experience? Cause no one complains about the speed and scrolling on an iPhone? The Gaming on an iPhone is great (for a mobile phone) so what really would the purpose be of a 120Hz screen on an iPhone? Maybe I am missing something. Cause all the reviewers emphasise the SMOOTH SCROLLING but I think most people would agree that the scrolling on an iPhone is already smooth, so what really would be the benefit of having a 120Hz screen on an iphone given what it is able to do now?

It's just a gimmick that's nice to have. 120hz is basically animations on turbo mode which consumes a lot of battery.
For that reason, I am not a fan. But a lot of people like it. I don't see why iphone needs a 120hz. It's already smooth enough.

I've had a OnePlus 7 Pro for almost a year now and I'm not considering upgrading. The hole-punch is a big turn off for me as I watch a lot of widescreen content and despite knowing that I'd get used to it, I really like having that full-screen experience. The increase to 120Hz is a welcome inclusion though. Increasing the price by like $300 seems a bit much too as the OP7 Pro was still waterproof just not certified and wireless charging doesn't seem to be that popular here in the UK. I love 1+ and their phones and I'm sure I'll keep buying them but I'm definitely not spending significantly more money on a phone that's got some downsides over my current one.

Why is no one making a HUGE deal about the prices? The 8 Pro went up MORE THAN $200, and the 8 went up about $150. These are crazy price jumps, and by no means are these "budget" options anymore.

@Mr H But, it had water resistance regardless (sufficient for me), and wireless charging is a costly (not just in price but space) addition that they clearly didn't implement very well (only 5W Qi wireless charging). Together, those are absolutely not worth over $200 in my opinion.

The cameras were fine on the 7 Pro, and they really don't seem to be that much better here. If the 8 Pro had pixel-quality cameras, I would be much more impressed.
@Brice I had it... No ip rating, no wireless charging, cameras were just OK... This is way better and cheaper than other top end phones.

@Mr H It's not much cheaper at all, and I would say the OnePlus 7 Pro was already a "true flagship phone", the best out there for its team in my opinion. It's just another flagship-price phone with little differentiating it. I think you can tell Marques isn't as excited about the 8 Pro as past devices, and he seems much less enthusiastic to announce and also does not recommend it like previous phones. Even just in the way he showed off the 8 Pro through the camera, it didn't compare to the effort taken to display the 7 Pro or 6T before it. Although this could be the phone for someone, I think OnePlus has lost most of its appeal in this device, not just in price but in a number of other ways like no pop-up camera. As a OnePlus user, if this is the approach going forward, I might never buy a phone from them again.
But you finally get a true flagship phone with great camera's cheaper than the top iPhones and the S20 ultra
